channel.title: Stupid math question
channel.description:
A classroom contains 31 chairs, some of which have arms and some of which do not. If the room contains 5 more armchairs than chairs without arms, how many armchairs does it contain?
[size=1]Answer is apparently 18[/size]

item.title: Stupid math question
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

(2a + 2c + b)/6 = 20

We know b = 30. How? Look at this example (with knowing that a < b < c)
a = 1, b = 2, c = 3
1 1 2(median) 3 3
So since the median is 30, b is 30.

Now (2a + 2c + 30)/6 = 20
2a/6 + 2c/6 + 5 = 20
2a/6 + 2c/6 = 15
2a + 2c = 90
a + c = 45

For the second one, the shaded region is just A and B correct, not C?

Read full topic

item.title: Stupid math question
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:7, topic:432487”]Yup And if you were trying to find the number of chairs without arms, it’d just be
(31-5)/2 = 13

PS - What level of math is this for? By the end of first year algebra you’re supposed to be able to do stuff like this in your head[/quote]

Actually sounds like a PSAT question. Sec I’ll get my book and post a few.

Here are some questions the PSAT labeled “hard”

  1. The average (arithmetic mean) and median of the five numbers, a, a, b, c, and c are 20 and 30, respectively, If a < b < c, what is the value of a+c?


  2. In the figure above, circular region A represents all integers from 10 to 100; circular region B represents all integers that are multiples of 3; and circular region C represents all squares of integers. How many regions are represented by the shaded region?

(A) 24
(B) 25
© 26
(D) 27
(E) 28

Read full topic

item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:5, topic:432487”]Brotip:

Numberofchairs/2 + difference/2
31/2 + 5/2 = 18

(or just (31+5)/2)[/quote]

I over thought it. Meh.

item.title: Stupid math question
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:1, topic:432487”]A classroom contains 31 chairs, some of which have arms and some of which do not. If the room contains 5 more armchairs than chairs without arms, how many armchairs does it contain?

[size=1]Answer is apparently 16[/size][/quote]

hmm… I don’t understand how it is 16… here’s my work,

y = armchairs
x = chairs

x+y=31

x+5 = y

x+(x+5) = 31

2x + 5 = 31
2x = 26

x = 13

13 + y = 31

y = 18

18 is what I got.

Edit: Yeah just did it again, it’s impossible to get 16 unless I misread something. 16 + 15 = 31. 15 chairs and 16 armchairs. armchairs do not have 5 more than chairs.

Read full topic
